string_table.name: npxnabnsnfns01001010001
string_table.string: Use your arrow keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

terms.term: Formation of soluble organic compounds and short-chain organic acids.

Ammonia from industrial sources, organic overloading, or from using anhydrous ammonia to correct a digester pH problem can cause a die-off of bacteria; ammonia toxicity begins around 1,500 mg/L and is totally toxic at 3,000 mg/L.

Biological stabilization process operated in the absence of oxygen in which the biodegradable matter in primary and secondary sludge is converted to methane gas, carbon dioxide, and other end products.
Solids destruction, solids stabilization, pathogen removal, biogas generation.

Biosolids that contain less than 1000 most probable number (MPN)/g of fecal coliforms and less than 3 MPN/4g of Salmonella bacteria and meet one of six stabilization alternatives given in 40 CFR 503. The material also must meet the pollutant limits and vector attraction reduction requirements set forth in 40 CFR 503.

Contain less than 2 million colony-forming units (CFU) or most probable number (MPN) of fecal coliforms per gram of dry biosolids. The material also must meet the pollutant limits and vector attraction reduction requirements set forth in 40 CFR 503.

Digester failure conditions are marked by conditions which include: Increase in involatile acid concentration, Increase in volatile acids-to-alkalinity ratio, Drop in pH, Drop in gas production, Increase in CO2 concentration.
Contributors to toxicity issues include high concentrations of ammonia and toxic metals such as arsenic, cadmium, chromium (hexavalent), copper, nickel, zinc.
The process of biologically degrading organic matter in sludge and reducing the concentrations of volatile solids and pathogens.
Polution concentration limits, Pathogen reduction standards, and Vector attraction reduction.
In the anaerobic digestion process microorganisms convert volatile matter into mainly methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2).
Reducing the sludge viscosity, converting complex organic matter to simpler compounds.

Anaerobic digestion that occurs in a temperature range of 85 °F to 100 °F. Most common operating temperatures for mesophilic digesters is between 95 °F to 98 °F and the typical number of days required for digestion is between 15 to 30 days SRT. The sludge at the end of this process is capable of meeting Class B biosolids requirements.
Converting volatile acids (formed in Step 2) into methane and carbon dioxide.
The major nutrients required for anaerobic digestion are nitrogen and phosphorus.
The amount of digester influent being pumped, and the percent Volatile Solids (VS) of the waste are a measure of the digester’s organic loading rate (influent mass per time).

pH is the concentration of acid protons [H+]. On the other hand, the alkalinity of a solution is its ability to neutralize acids. Alkalinity consists of ions that incorporate acid protons into their molecules so that they are not available as a free acid that can lower the pH
SRT is calculated by dividing the digester volume by the daily sludge flow.
A treatment process designed to reduce the number of pathogens in sludge, to reduce the attraction of vectors, and to prevent the release of harmful chemicals from wastes.
The anaerobic digestion is temperature sensitive and temperature of the sludge in the digester needs to be controlled to ensure proper operation.

TPAD is an approach that incorporates the advantages of thermophilic digestion and decreases the disadvantages through the addition of a mesophilic phase that enhances stabilization. The process can operate in either of two modes, thermophilic-mesophilic or mesophilic-thermophilic. Because of greater hydrolysis and biological activity in the thermophilic phase, this process has greater VSS destruction and gas production. The process is capable of meeting Class A biosolids requirements.

Anaerobic digestion that occurs in a temperature range of 122 °F to 135 °F and it typically requires 5 to 12 days SRT. The sludge at the end of this process is capable of meeting Class A biosolids requirements.
The volatile acid-to-alkalinity ratio indicates if the digester has enough buffering capacity for the volatile acids being produced.

Digester volatile solids concentration is typically expressed as a percentage of the sludge total solids. The digester conditions are maintained to ensure optimal conditions conducive to the activity of the methane formers. Good digester operations require ensuring that conditions are kept favorable for the methane formers.
